query: Which documents would be most compelling to a tribunal?
output:
CLAUDE CODE ANALYSIS
Query: Which documents would be most compelling to a tribunal?

RELEVANT DOCUMENT EXCERPTS:

[Bassim Draft Witness Statement.docx, p.1]
I make this declaration based upon my personal knowledge and upon a review of documents and correspondence kept in the ordinary course of business, except for those statements made upon information and belief, and these I believe to be true.

[Bassim Draft Witness Statement.docx, p.1]
After the Aircraft was finally returned to service by Gulfstream around November 29, 2024 (approximately 10 months after input), CITIOM eventually sold the Aircraft. However, due to the market conditions and the aircraft's troubled maintenance history resulting from the 192-month inspection, the final sale price was approximately $1 million less than the price agreed upon in the failed May 2024 agreement. This represents a direct financial loss caused by Gulfstream's failure to meet its commitments. [CITE RECENT SALE DOCUMENTS]. I understand the buyers, who were experienced aircraft operators, were shocked by the final invoice amount from the 192-month inspection.

[CITIOM v. GAC - Confidentiality Agreement and Proposed Protective Order.pdf, p.2]
documents, deposition transcripts, expert reports, briefs, testimony, filings, and any other

[CITIOM v. GAC - Confidentiality Agreement and Proposed Protective Order.pdf, p.8]
information. Gulfstream has also represented that in lieu of designating certain documents and

[CITIOM v. GAC - Confidentiality Agreement and Proposed Protective Order.pdf, p.12]
not be permitted to retain copies of documents containing Confidential Material without an Order

[CITIOM v. GAC - Confidentiality Agreement and Proposed Protective Order.pdf, p.12]
documents containing Highly Confidential Material without written agreement of the Disclosing

[CITIOM v. GAC - Confidentiality Agreement and Proposed Protective Order.pdf, p.12]
their files documents containing information derived from any Confidential or Highly Confidential

[CITIOM v. GAC - Confidentiality Agreement and Proposed Protective Order.pdf, p.14]
Material may be made at any time, the Disclosing Party should endeavor to designate documents

[CITIOM v. GAC - Confidentiality Agreement and Proposed Protective Order.pdf, p.14]
Pleadings or Briefs Referencing Confidential Material. All documents of any

[CITIOM v. GAC - Confidentiality Agreement and Proposed Protective Order.pdf, p.14]
documents of any nature, including briefs, which contain or refer, directly or indirectly, to the content

[Danny Farnham Direct Outline with Cross & Redirect.docx, p.1]
Would proper inspection or treatment during those events have prevented recurrence?

[Danny Farnham Direct Outline with Cross & Redirect.docx, p.1]
How would you describe the staffing levels you observed at St. Louis?

[Danny Farnham Direct Outline with Cross & Redirect.docx, p.1]
Would adherence to industry norms and proactive planning have avoided most of these issues?

[Danny Farnham Direct Outline with Cross & Redirect.docx, p.1]
1. “We couldn’t have known discrepancies would arise”

[Danny Farnham Direct Outline with Cross & Redirect.docx, p.1]
Beauchemin / Gulfstream Position: That would be speculative.



Based on document search, key findings:
- Found relevant excerpts in repository documents
- See excerpts above for specific citations
